dmacro-examples

exploration of dynamic macroeconomic models aimed to (self) teaching

View the Project on GitHub ricardomayerb/dmacro-examples

  • Download ZIP File
  • Download TAR Ball
  • View On GitHub

Welcome to dmacro-examples.

Here I'll take a few dynamic macroeconomic models and use them to explore the models themselves but more importantly some computational, economic and theoretical issues using the same models as plataforms. For instance, I'll take a basic RBC model, show you some of the details behind them, but then I'll add learning and model uncertainty to help you understand those variation in information.

Sections

  • Simple ('toy') model with non-stationary TFP: preparing the way to add imperfect information, first, and model uncertainty, later, to investigate interation between productivity trend and labor

    • Introduction
    • Model presentation
    • Balanced Growth Path and transformation of variables
    • new Balanced Growth Path

  • Notes on the bibliography : comments and schedules of reading regarding books and papers relevant to the toy model.

  • Programming: software set-up instructions, comments, programming examples, programming assignments, etc.

  • Math notes : commented examples and problems sets with mathematical exercises.

  • Some other comments/instructions can been seen at project's Wiki (at the GitHub repository).

Rather Drive Stick?

If you prefer to not use the automatic generator, push a branch named gh-pages to your repository to create a page manually. In addition to supporting regular HTML content, GitHub Pages support Jekyll, a simple, blog aware static site generator written by our own Tom Preston-Werner. Jekyll makes it easy to create site-wide headers and footers without having to copy them across every page. It also offers intelligent blog support and other advanced templating features.
